Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine, we're only a few hundred miles from the coast of France. Breathe in that sea air - doesn't it smell like home?
Triomphant, come over here. Listen to this.
... You cannot stand against me, against my sisters. Surrender now. You cannot stand...
Je ne comprends pas - is that a Morgana? Is this live? Who is hearing this?
A friend of mine in France told me about the broadcast.
Apparently, Despair has been haunting these waters for some time, broadcasting from an unknown location as a means of disillusioning those on the southern coast.
What? Oh, I will not stand for this.
Do you have a plan in mind?

Fields.MenuText: If so, rest assured that you have my full support.
Make sure you run it past me before you proceed.
Heh, should I be concerned?

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Capitaine. Knowing that means a lot to me.
Oui, Capitaine, of course.
No, you shouldn't be, thank you very much.
Captain, Triomphant, we've spotted a Morgana group! They're attacking a civilian ship!
Let's go.
@BATTLE
Triomphant, the civilians we rescued in our last battle are trying to settle in.
Je pense que oui.
I'm glad to see it. They need a chance to recover.

Fields.MenuText: Would you mind lending a hand, if you see an opportunity?
Do whatever you can to help.
Are you capable of lifting luggage? You're not the most muscular supernatural entity I've ever seen.

Fields.DialogueText: I would be happy to, Capitaine!
Of course.
Your confidence in my ability means so much to me.
Monsieur! Bonjour! Look at all your luggage. Allow me to assist you, please.
I'm not in need of help.
Watch out! You're about to lose one of your bags!
*BAM*
Here, here, let me help. Everything looks unscathed, not to worry.
Hmph. Well, thank you.
Robert Lockhart? Is that your name? I see it written here, on the side of your bag.
You're correct on that count.
Well, Monsieur Lockhart, it's a pleasure. Here is your bag. And - oh, look, I missed something. Is this... this is a microphone, isn't it?
Put that back in my bag.
Je suis désolée, Monsieur, my apologies. There, now everything is where it should be.
If you need any help in the future, don't be afraid to ask! Je suis Triomphant. I'm at your service.
Yeah, yeah, yeah...
Making friends, Triomphant?
Give it time, Capitaine. I can make friends with just about anyone. Now, there are Morganas headed this direction - we should go.
@BATTLE
Huh.
That is quite the mound of food on your plate, Triomphant.
Do you think so, Capitaine?

Fields.MenuText: I'm impressed you're able to eat that much!
It looks like more than your allotted portion, in fact.
You eat like that, you're going to gain weight.

Fields.DialogueText: It takes a lot of fuel to keep someone as energetic as myself running!
Not to worry - Officer Soo was feeling ill and told me I could have her portion.
I only take so much to ensure that you don't do the same.
I was hoping to speak to you concerning our battle strategies moving forward. Triomphant? Are you listening to me?
Shh, Capitaine, just a moment. Do you hear what Officer Bell is saying?
... My father told me all about Robert Lockhart. He operated an outlaw radio station in Europe during the Great War, and inspired thousands of soldiers with his broadcasts.
I can't believe he's on this ship with us, right now!
Monsieur Lockhart? That was the man I helped; the gruff one with the microphone. How interesting...
Is it?
It could be.
Well... all right, then.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. Let's go.
@BATTLE
Capitaine!
Yes, Triomphant?
I had a request. I was wondering if it would be possible for me to put in an order for some old audio recordings. Ones made during the Great War.
Am I to assume this has something to do with Robert Lockhart?
I would say that's a fair possibility.

Fields.MenuText: Go right ahead! I'm interested to see what you're planning.
You have my permission, but check with me before you take any further action.
Tell me - should I feel worried?

Fields.DialogueText: Merci, Capitaine! I'm hopeful that my idea is a good one.
Of course, Capitaine. I will let you know.
No, of course not.
Sir! We have a Morgana headed this way!
You think you can wait until after the battle to put in your order?
I think I'm up to the task.
@BATTLE
... Lesser men and women would run in the face of such adversity. But you, you men and women who serve on the frontlines of this great war...
... your efforts will not be in vain. Your courage secures the future of the human race...
That's quite the speech, Triomphant. Is that a recording of Robert Lockhart's?
*SNIFFLE*
Oui, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: I can see why you would be so moved. It was quite inspiring.
Come now, Triomphant. There is no room for tears in war.
Oh, is someone a little emotional? That's just heartwarming.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed, he had such a gracious heart for those fighting in that war.
Sorry, sorry, Capitaine. I'm generally not this emotional.
Better a warm heart than other maladies. Vous avez le cerveau d'un sandwich au fromage.
Mmhmm. And have you decided on a plan of action?
I have. If Despair's broadcasts are affecting the morale of my people, then it's up to me to combat her efforts. As long as we don't know where she is, we can't do so physically.
But I think Monsieur Lockhart could help us lift their spirits in another way.
Captain - I'm about to sound the alarm. We have Morganas headed in from the northeast.
Come on, Triomphant. Time to go.
@BATTLE
Triomphant? What are we looking at?
Over there, Capitaine - there's Monsieur Lockhart. I'm going to ask for his help.
Ah, yes. Going to put your plan into action?

Fields.MenuText: If you need my assistance, let me know. I'll be happy to help.
Remember that he's a guest on this ship, Triomphant. If he says no, don't pester him.
He looks as if he's in an even worse mood than the last time you saw him. This ought to go over well.

Fields.DialogueText: Merci, Capitaine. But I think I'll be all right.
I think a single man can endure a little pestering when the well-being of many is at stake.
Sometimes I wonder why I bring you along at all...
Oh, Monsieur Lockhart! Bonjour!
Hmph. You again?
Yes, me again. I recently overheard that you were something of a radio celebrity during the Great War, and I was wondering if...
No.
Excusez-moi?
I don't care what you want. The answer is no.
That could have gone better.
You aren't kidding. There's the alarm - I'll have to give this some thought while we fight.
@BATTLE
You look... contemplative.
Distracted, you mean. Excusez-moi.
I just wonder why Monsieur Lockhart is being so stubborn.
He has his reasons, I'm sure.

Fields.MenuText: Triomphant, there's Robert Lockhart. Are you going to try again?
Triomphant, are you planning on continuing to pester Mr. Lockhart, in spite of my orders not to?
Hey - look, Triomphant, it's Lockhart! You think he'll shoot you down as quickly as he did last time?

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, Capitaine. I can't give up.
Yes. My apologies, Capitaine, but I can't let up now. I can't forsake my people.
Taisez-vous.
Monsieur Lockhart?
Not again...
You might be thinking me a bit of a nuisance by now...
A bit?
... but I hope my insistence proves to you the seriousness of the request I'm putting before you.
The people of the French coast are being bombarded by broadcasts made by the Morgana Despair, and I fear that, the longer they're subjected to such words...
... the more they'll lose hope. I've heard your old broadcasts from the Great War, and I know that you could bring confidence to the French people.
Monsieur Lockhart?
... I made hundreds of broadcasts over the course of the Great War, granting people the hope of which you speak. Tell me, Mademoiselle, what do I have to show for it?
What?
Look where we are. Another war. Like it or not, this Despair is only preparing your people for the inevitable future. Even if this war is won, another will take its place in due time.
War, decline and death are inevitable. There is no reason to fight against it.
Good grief, Triomphant. That was as dispiriting a rejection as I've ever witnessed. Sorry.
You think that was enough to make me give up, Capitaine? Clearly, you don't know me well. Now come, there's a Morgana headed our way.
@BATTLE
Monsieur Lockhart!
Do you never give up?
You said war, decline and death are inevitable. Well, I'm here to respectfully tell you that there is one more inevitability, one which you've missed.
Heh. Tell me, what did I miss?
Me. When I'm in the pursuit of doing what's right, nothing will stand in my way.
And since you feel the need to give in to war and decline and death, you might as well give into me as well. Because I won't stop until you do.
Captain - what do you have to say about this Belle harassing me?

Fields.MenuText: Triomphant's moral compass is so unwavering, I wouldn't dare deter her.
I do not approve of her pestering you, and she knows as much. But she is acting in the best interest of those I've been called to protect.
Harassment? Please. Is she annoying? Yes. But I hardly think you could call this harassment.

Fields.DialogueText: Your support means a lot to me, Capitaine.
Merci. I appreciate your understanding.
Such a help you are in my times of need, Capitaine.
Well, then, it appears I have no choice, doesn't it? But if I'm being forced to participate, I insist that our broadcasts be done my way.
Absolutely. Thank you, Monsieur Lockhart! I promise, you won't regret this.
Sure...
Captain, we have Morganas headed in from the south.
All right. Come on, Triomphant.
@BATTLE
Goodness, Capitaine, look at all of this recording equipment. Monsieur Lockhart, this is quite impressive!
Don't touch that.
Oui, Monsieur. My apologies.

Fields.MenuText: Don't worry, Triomphant. I'm sure he'll relax once you start working.
His equipment is impeccably clean. Hardly a surprise he doesn't want other hands messing with things.
I see someone's sparkling personality is still intact.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm still just stunned he agreed to help at all.
Oui, of course, Capitaine.
He could use a little socialization, couldn't he?
Now, Triomphant, come here. Sit in this chair. You'll be giving the broadcast.
Me? Oh, no, that isn't a good idea, I am... not a good performer. And you're the one with all the experience. If anyone could inspire my people, it's you.
Inspiring really isn't what we'll be working toward.
What?
You don't want to just give your people hope. Optimally, you'd like to drive the Morgana away as well. And I'm confident that this broadcast could be capable of doing both.
This is my idea. You pose as a Morgana. You already have the voice for it. And during your broadcast, you make continued mention of how inept the Morganas are.
They'll be lies, of course. But the people will think the Morganas are fallible. And if we're lucky, the Morganas will be so fed up, they'll give up their broadcasts.
Triomphant, I really don't know if this is a good idea. It might only serve to enrage Despair.
I know, but I have to risk it, Capitaine. The thing that will give my people the most hope is being rid of Despair's broadcasts for good.
As long as we remain unaware of where Despair is broadcasting, we're incapable of physically stopping her.
Monsieur Lockhart's plan is our only recourse. Now, there's the alarm. Come now, let's go.
@BATTLE
Go ahead, Triomphant. Just like we've practiced.
Okay. Okay. Um... P-people of France. It is I, the Morgana, Shame!
You will... bow before me! There is no escape! Except... wait! One of my turrets just... fell. Oh, no.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, she could still use some practice.
Somehow, I don't think this broadcast will have the effect Triomphant was hoping for.
*snorts*

Fields.DialogueText: That's the understatement of the year.
I wanted an inept Morgana. This one... certainly sounds inept.
You snort on my equipment, you pay for new equipment.
Is there anything she can do to improve? Is she really this bad of an actress?
She's stiff on mic. I've seen it with actresses in the past. She's too tense; she needs to loosen up.
We'll have to figure out some way of helping her do so before the next broadcast.
*ALARM*
Oh... there's the alarm! I mean... that alarm, it's the sound of your coming doom! Just wait!
Oh, boy.
@BATTLE
We're holding off on another broadcast to spend more time in practice.
At what point do we admit that no amount of practice can help a performer as terrible as myself?
Sit down. You too, Captain, please. Triomphant, look at me. Are you looking at me?
Yes, Monsieur Lockhart, I'm looking at you.
I had hoped to avoid this, but I'm going to show you how you ought to deliver the words you've memorized. Now, how do I look?
You look quite relaxed.
Yes, very good. I'm relaxed. I'm breathing. My feet are planted on the floor. I'm calm. You must learn to start each broadcast in a state of ease.
Then, you consider your role. Not the effect you want it to have on others - otherwise, you'll become anxious. For your broadcasts, all that matters is Shame, your Morgana.
And then, once you're at ease and focused on your character, you begin.
Prepare yourselves, people of France, for I am coming for you. I, Shame, the strongest of the Morganas, more competent in battle than my fool of a sister Despair.
She might sink under the weight of her own melancholy, but I, I will bring you doom!

Fields.MenuText: This is one of the more entertaining things I've ever seen.
While I remain wary of this plan of action, I must admit he is humorous.
I mean, it's entertainment gold, but I can also think of about fifty-three ways this could go badly.

Fields.DialogueText: Isn't it? If I were able to do that, maybe Despair really would get fed up and leave!
Thank you for admitting as much, Capitaine.
Yes, yes, I know.
Relaxed. Breathing. Feet planted. At ease. Focused. I can do this.
There's the alarm.
I can do this after we fight a Morgana.
@BATTLE
... Rest assured, I will overcome the laziness and inability of my sisters!
Je ne vais pas faiblir! Je ne serai pas arrêtée!
This is incredible!

Fields.MenuText: What a broadcast! She did wonderfully!
Now we have to wait and see what effect this has on Despair.
That was certainly a quick uptick in acting ability on her part, wasn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: Calm down, kid. She's no Ingrid Bergman.
Well, aren't we just a pair of optimists?
You're a smarmy upstart, you know that?
You're off the air, Triomphant.
Did you see me, Capitaine? Did you see me!? Monsieur Lockhart, I'll admit, when you first hatched this scheme, I thought there was no way I would be up to the task.
But after taking part, I must say it was the singular most thrilling experience of my entire life!
All right, all right, Triomphant. Calm down before you hurt yourself.
Yes, of course.
You did well for a beginner, Triomphant. With continued broadcasts, your skills will only continue to develop.
There's a Morgana incoming, Capitaine, to our west. You ready to go? I'm ready to go!
Oh, she is very excitable sometimes.
@BATTLE
That was a great program, Triomphant!
Oh, merci! That's so sweet of you!
Really, an excellent job. Way to show that Morgana!
Thank you, thank you! And please, tell Monsieur Lockhart as much when you see him - he was the mastermind behind it all!

Fields.MenuText: The officers on board are really responding well to the show, Triomphant!
Don't get carried away by all this praise, Triomphant. Remember, you have duties to attend to.
The life of a celebrity. Can I get you anything, your highness? Soda water? A lapdog?

Fields.DialogueText: I know, I just hope the people in France feel similarly.
Yes, of course, Capitaine. I've seen to all my duties on board today.
Soda water, no. Lapdog, well...
Come on, now, Triomphant. We need to start rehearsing your next show.
Already? But we just shot the first!
Such is the life of an entertainer. The stories I could tell you of the late-night rehearsals I've participated in...
Would you? I adore a good story, Monsieur Lockhart.
Actually, Triomphant, Mr. Lockhart, I'm afraid that's the alarm. The stories will have to wait.
@BATTLE
Triomphant, come here, please.
Bien sûr. How can I help?
I want you to sit down for a moment.
Why? Is something wrong? Did someone die? What's happened?

Fields.MenuText: No, nothing is wrong, I assure you.
Patience, Triomphant, please. Sit, and I will tell you.
Yes. Everyone died. The world has ended. This is the afterlife. Turns out it's just as terrible as the land of the living.

Fields.DialogueText: Then, tell me, please. What's going on?
Oui, Capitaine. Of course.
You mean I'm stuck with you for all of eternity? Dieu, what did I do to deserve such a fate?
I heard from my friend in France. The people on the French coast heard your broadcast.
And they loved it.
Really? You're serious?
Yes, I'm serious. Apparently, they haven't been this invigorated since before the war began. So, congratulations are in order, I believe.
I can't believe it. That - it's just - it's so wonderful. I'm so happy they're happy. I need to go tell Monsieur Lockhart!
Captain, Triomphant - we have Morganas inbound.
Thank you, officer. We'll be there shortly.
@BATTLE
Triomphant?
Oui, Capitaine?

Fields.MenuText: Is everything all right? You look pale.
You're not getting seasick, are you?
Do Belles throw up? I can't decide whether or not that's something I'd want to see...

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, yes, I'm fine.
No, sir. I assure you, I'm well.
That's disgusting. You're disgusting.
I'm not ill, I'm shocked.
Shocked? Why?
Monsieur Lockhart and I tuned into Despair's latest broadcast, only... there wasn't one. It was just static.
You're kidding.
I'm not! We listened to static for an hour, straight through, just in case it started late. But nothing came.
You think...?
I'm not sure what to think. But, if on the off chance that's it? If Despair's given up on her broadcasts altogether?
You're seconds away from losing it, aren't you? You're that excited.
More or less!
Well, there's the alarm. Why don't you take some of that excitement out on a Morgana?
Avec plaisir.
@BATTLE
Monsieur Lockhart! I've found more food for our celebration!
Triomphant, I assure you, you don't need to go to this much trouble.
But of course I do!
The two of you did a good thing, Mr. Lockhart. A little festivity wouldn't hurt.
Here you go, Capitaine. More wine, more cheese.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you, Triomphant. You're quite the hostess, you know that?
I appreciate the gesture, but I'm about to return to my duties. I think I should forgo additional food.
You are very stereotypically French, you know that?

Fields.DialogueText: Food makes everyone happy, and I'm happy when others are happy.
Oh, of course, Capitaine.
You're stereotypical in certain ways as well, but I'm too polite to name them specifically.
Captain, could I speak to you for a moment? I have a message to relay.
Yes, I'll be right there.
I've been giving thought to our next broadcast, Triomphant. We can't let up now; otherwise Despair might read our absence as an invitation to return.
I completely agree, Monsieur. And - speaking of Despair, I believe there is a Morgana group not far from us. Return to your quarters. I'll go sound the alarm.
@BATTLE
Triomphant? Mr. Lockhart?
Goodness, Capitaine, what is it? You look so grim.
I just received word from my friend in France. Despair has emerged. She and a mass of other Morganas just attacked the coast.  More than a dozen ships were lost.
Oh, no.
What's more, survivors have reported hearing the Morganas blame their actions on your broadcast. It seems Despair was content to merely disillusion the French people...
... but she was so enraged by your broadcast that she decided to fight instead.
Sir, we have another Morgana force headed our way.
Triomphant, I'm sorry. I know you meant well. But you have to put it out of your mind for the time being. I need you ready to fight.
@BATTLE
*knock*
Triomphant? Are you in there?

Fields.MenuText: Triomphant, please come out. We need to speak about what's happened. You need to speak about what's happened.
Out of that room, Triomphant. You have your duties to attend to.
Come on, Triomphant, moaning and groaning about what's happened isn't going to help anything.

Fields.DialogueText: The attack... I know you're blaming yourself for what happened. But you can't do that.
... You warned me about what might happen. I forged ahead. I am absolutely to blame.
But...
We have Morganas coming in from the south. Let's go.
... All right.
@BATTLE
I'm telling you, Triomphant, this continually blaming yourself isn't good. You're...
I've heard your opinion on the subject, Capitaine. But I'm afraid I'm not readily capable of compartmentalizing grief. Or shame, fittingly enough.
You...
Excuse me?
You, your voice! You're Shame, that sham of a Morgana! You're the one who provoked Despair!

Fields.MenuText: Ma'am, I appreciate how difficult this time must be for you, but Despair is at fault for what happened. No one else.
Ma'am, you are a guest on this ship. Do not antagonize my crew.
Oh, and is your outburst really helping matters? Get back to your cabin before I have someone escort you there.

Fields.DialogueText: You're wrong, Capitaine. Despair might have done the damage, but I was the one who lit the fuse.
She was only speaking truth, Capitaine.
There's no need to be so protective, Capitaine.
I deserve those words.
Captain, Triomphant - we have another incoming Morgana group. Ma'am, please follow me below deck.
Triomphant...
@BATTLE
*sigh*
Triomphant?
I suppose, after I relentlessly pursued Monsieur Lockhart, it's only fitting that I be on the receiving end of persistence.

Fields.MenuText: I only want to help you in whatever way I can.
You're a part of my crew. If you're not at your best, then none of us are.
Ironic, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: I know that to be true, Capitaine.
I appreciate your consideration, sir.
It's less irony and more an unhappy coincidence, if you want to be technical about it.
Are you ready to listen to what I have to say?
Have you not said it yet? What have you been saying to me all this time, if not what you've been meaning to say?
My apologies. Yes, I am listening.
The French people need you, Triomphant.
No, they do not.
Yes, they do. Their morale has never been lower. They need to know that you're on their side. Not Shame. Triomphant.
Despair has emerged from hiding. So you need to tell your people you're with them, and then you need to do what you can to drive her away. Prove yourself to them.
And you think I'm up to the task?
Does that matter? Or is the well-being of your people all that matters?
Captain - Morganas are headed this way! I'm about to sound the alarm.
I have some things to consider while we fight.
@BATTLE
There's Monsieur Lockhart, Capitaine. We need him if we're going to send a message to the French people.
Understood.
That said...

Fields.MenuText: He looks... slightly inebriated.
I see he smuggled alcohol aboard my ship.
Is that bourbon? You know, I could go for some bourbon right about now.

Fields.DialogueText: Slightly? He looks as if he's barely keeping upright.
Certainly not the first time that's happened.
Why don't we keep our eyes on the goal here, Capitaine?
Monsieur Lockhart? Why don't you put down that glass. I think you've had enough to drink for the day.
Or year.
I told you, didn't I, Mademoiselle? War and defeat and death. Long term, they are only inevitabilities.
Officer? Would you escort Mr. Lockhart to his cabin? Ensure he stays there until he sobers up.
Oui, Capitaine. Additionally, we have more Morganas inbound.
Wonderful.
Let's go, Triomphant.
@BATTLE
Capitaine? What are you trying to do to Monsieur Lockhart's cabin door?
I came to check on him, but he's barricaded himself inside. Looks as if he doesn't want any pesky visitors.
And you thought bashing your way through his door to be the best solution?

Fields.MenuText: Do you have another idea in mind?
Don't play coy, Triomphant. What are you thinking?
Yes.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, I do.
My apologies, Capitaine.
Unsurprising.
First, let's remember that I'm capable of phasing my way through solid objects.
... I forgot about that one.
And second, when I phase into his room and open the door, we need to have a plan. He's despondent enough. Making it up as we go along won't be effective.
Fortunately, I have a plan. There's a Morgana group north of us.
That's your plan?
No, of course not. Morganas will arrive, we'll take care of them, and then I'll tell you my plan.
@BATTLE
Monsieur Lockhart!
H-how did you get in here? Don't do that, don't open the door! Oh, I really don't like you, you know that?
Mr. Lockhart, it's good to see you more clear-headed. Have you met Officer Bell?
No...
Officer Bell, please, go ahead.
Mr. Lockhart, it's an honor meeting you. My father heard your broadcasts during the Great War. And once he arrived home, he made it clear -
You were what got him through that war. Your words of encouragement got him through each moment.
I understand your thinking, Monsieur. Perhaps war and decline and death are inevitable, in the long-term. But the long-term isn't all that matters.
The present moment is just as important. It was important for Officer Bell's father. And it's important for the French people, right now.
They're hurting. And as I am primarily responsible for their current hurt, I think it's right that I do something to ease that pain. But I can't do it without you.
Monsieur?
... Well, Triomphant, it appears I'm unable to say no to you for any consistent length of time. Do you have a plan?
I do. I've written it down for you.

Fields.MenuText: There's the alarm, Triomphant.

Fields.DialogueText: @BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Mr. Lockhart, please consider Triomphant's plan.
Officer Bell, thank you for your help.

Fields.DialogueText: Five to places.
You break it, you bought it, as they say. I'm inclined to assist in the buying.
Sir! I'm just glad my favorite show's coming back on the air.
All right, Triomphant.
Everything's set. We're just waiting on you.
I am ready, Monsieur.

Fields.MenuText: I know you can do this, Triomphant.
It takes a lot of resolve to do what you're doing, Triomphant. I respect that.
Break a leg... or, you know, whatever you say in these sorts of situations.

Fields.DialogueText: You have more confidence than I do... but thank you.
Merci, Capitaine. That means a lot.
Your encouragement skills could use some work.
Ready?
Ready.
People of France. My name is Triomphant. You've heard my voice before, speaking as a Morgana named Shame.
A character I played, in the hopes that I could give you hope, and drive Despair from your waters. But, I failed you, and that failure will haunt me for years to come.
Your future may seem uncertain, but hear me now - I will not abandon you to Despair. You are my people, and as long as I am alive, I will endeavor to protect you.
Sir, we have more Morganas headed this way.
We'll be there in one minute.
And hear me, Despair. Your fight is not with my people. Your fight is with me. Find me. And face me.
She can have a certain gravitas, can't she?
She certainly can.
@BATTLE
Any sign of Despair yet, Capitaine?
Not yet. But I'm confident she'll appear soon enough.
Capitaine...
What is it?
I just wanted to thank you. You could have made me feel terrible for not following your warning. But you encouraged me. I appreciate that a lot.
Well, not everyone could pick themselves up as quickly or as confidently as you've done. You've impressed me, Triomphant.

Fields.MenuText: This could be quite the partnership.
Why do my knees feel as if they've just turned to jelly?

Fields.DialogueText: @BATTLE
Sir, we've spotted Despair! She's headed this way!
This is it, Capitaine. She won't stand a chance against the two of us, will she?
No, I don't think so.
*ALARM*
